title-group.article-title: Vishalyakarani as "Eupatonum ayapana": Retrobotanizing, Embedded Traditions, and Multiple Historicities of Plants in Colonial Bengal, 1890-1940

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2014 Association for Asian Studies, Inc.

abstract.p: This article critically examines the assumptions and processes involved in identifying histoncally distinctive plant identities by their Latin botanical names. By following latecolonial efforts to identify a medicinal herb mentioned in some versions of the Ramayana, this paper argues for a historicist analysis of the process of "retro-botanizing." In so doing, it also distinguishes between two different forms of "tradition," the "factualized" and "embedded." Finally, it blurs the allegedly watertight distinction between histoncal and mythic pasts. Instead of trying to distinguish these pasts ontologically, I argue that it is more productive to see specific pasts in relation to the sorts of futures they produce, that is, their respective historicities.
